title: Commander Keen in: The Tantalus Wars
content:
NOTE (11/12/06): the new engine will be programmed in C++ (Dev C++), and I'm looking into programming graphics in either DirectX or OpenGL, depending on which one is easier for me to learn. So yes, this won't be coming out anytime soon.

Well, here's the new thread for my project. I created a new thread because I have a title, and a story which I want to be viewed *first* and not some programming problems.

From the previous thread:
MortimerInBlack: Yes, I could use some programming help in GM. Do you haev a YIM, AIM, or MSN handle?

Here are two screen shots (These aren't from the game, but concepts for tiles), so if you were wondering what the "3D graphics" meant, here it is, but be forewarned that the GIF extension takes away a lot of colours.)

[img]http://www.geocities.com/globox88/ConceptScreen0.gif[/img]
[img]http://www.geocities.com/globox88/ConceptScreen0.gif[/img]

[img]http://www.geocities.com/globox88/ConceptScreen1.gif[/img]
[img]http://www.geocities.com/globox88/ConceptScreen1.gif[/img]

Commander Keen in: The Tantalus Wars

The Story:

One brown-haired boy lay upon his bed. He wore pink bunny slippers, sky-blue pajamas, and patches of freckles. He was nine years old. He woke from his sleep by the sounds of his mother.

"Billy, get up now." yelled a voice from downstairs.

Billy grumbled and rolled over.

*Knock* *Knock*

Billy's mother came into the room and yelled some more. Billy yawned and assured her that he was up. He sat in bed for a moment thinking. He had just come back from the Altair sector last night, after going on a "week long vacation with Bobby Stone." --or so he told his parents. Ever since the defeat of Mortimer, the galaxy had exploded into war. The power vacuum left by Mortimer after his demise led every space-traveling race into a conquest for an galactic empire.

Billy had joined the Vorticon's attack on the Altair system because it made a plentiful supply route for Vorticon Destroyers and Motherships. The Vorticons intended to keep peace in the galaxy; however, the Great Races, consisting of the Shikadi, Fleex, and Regelatins, made this a difficult objective.

Last night, the Vorticons also said their fleet had finally reached Korath III --the mainbase of the Shakadi. If the Shikadi could be subjugated, then one third of the Great Races fleet will be decimated. Unfortunetely, the Vorticons had no use for a single fighter ship, and said that the would need Keen for other missions.

Billy stretched, rubbed his eyes, and got dressed. Billy hopped downstairs, awaiting breakfast.

"Billy, you're going to need to feed that green thing of yours. It keeps on coming in here and poking me with its eye." said Billy's mom.

Billy sighed. He got up from his bowl of Sugar Stoopies; grabbed the dog food and walked out to his club house. As soon as he was out the door, Spot was smacking him with his eye.

"Son of a... What's gotten into you, Spot? Billy asked.

Spot tapped Billy's back pushing him into the Club House. The Photacyn Transceiver was buzzing like mad. Billy turned it on.

*Click*

"Keen... Attack... *bzz* Vorticon VI... They're here! *bzz* Captain Keen, we *bzz* your help! Come to Vorticon VI! The Fleex have sent a Shakadi cloak-ship over Vorticon VI!"

*Fades out*

"Damn."

He flew back into the house and up the stairs. He donned his brother helmet, snagged the Vorticon Hyper Pistol, and become Commander Keen: Defender of the Universe!

He ran backstairs, and leaped into the Bean-With-Bacon Megarocket.


He headed off to Vorticon VI and his next big adventure.

[End]~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: agreed
content:
I wish you luck learning either OpenGL or DirectX, Globox - whilst I'm sure you could master either with less than the amount of work and brainpower you've put in (Newtonian physics = eep, from what little I've failed to grasp) the learning processes for both are fairly mind-bending.

Since DirectX and OpenGL are both fairly similar in terms of how you code for them, I suggest learning DirectX; it's generally faster and more reliable than OpenGL (although I have no concrete evidence to prove either - any input on this, Malvineous?). You'll probably have better luck finding tutorials, docs and examples for DirectX too.[url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

title: Re: agreed
content:
I've briefly tried programming for both OpenGL and DirectX (albeit in the days of DirectX 6), and OpenGL is *much* easier to get started with, by a mile (or it was back then, anyway.)

DirectX is heavily object oriented, so you'll need to know C++ well enough that you fully understand classes, objects, pointers, instances, multiple inheritance, etc, etc. OpenGL on the other hand isn't object oriented at all, so you can use it in straight C programs, no knowledge of classes required.

Of course I'd also recommend OpenGL because it's cross-platform, but if you're only going to write a Windows version anyway then DirectX does also handle sound (and 3D sound at that), keyboard/mouse/whatever input, network multiplayer, etc. all within the same framework, whereas OpenGL is 3D graphics only.

There doesn't seem to be any shortage of tutorials for either option though, so have a look at a few and see what you think is more suitable. At the time I tried the DirectX stuff I knew C pretty well, but I was new to C++ so I only had a basic knowledge of classes - and I had to give up, because it was way too complicated for me back then [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: agreed
content:
I think "Developer Studio" is Microsoft's generic IDE - IIRC they changed its name to "Visual Studio" some years back.

As far as PNGs go, you might want to try the ImageMagick library instead - it makes using images *much* simpler than accessing the raw file data directly, and allows you to use a ton of different file formats too.

I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: agreed
content:
If you're referring to Developer Studio then maybe it's some other program, DevStudio is just an IDE (basically a glorified text editor that makes it easy to program, compile and debug programs.) The only image-related functions in an IDE are in some of the fancier ones where they allow you to draw icons for your program in them.

I'm not sure what you mean by "resource headers" - ImageMagick simply loads images from disk and stores the image data in memory (at runtime.) It's up to you to do something with that image data. It can do basic manipulation (resizing, mirroring, etc.) and can of course save the modified image back to disk, but the idea is that it gives you access to the raw pixels in the image and then gets out of the way.

I'll be using it in my game editor for importing images (say if you want to import a .png file over the top of the Cosmo title screen, the .png file will be read in using ImageMagick) and likewise when you export an image ImageMagick is used to create the file on disk (eventually in either .png or .tiff format, but to change formats it's only one function call to the ImageMagick library.)

title: Re: agreed
content:
If you're finding that you're not enjoying programming then you really should take a break and start off with something much simpler - you have to learn to walk before you can run cross country [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

DirectDraw and Direct3D will display images that you've *already* loaded into memory on-screen, but you still have to get the images into memory first. ImageMagick or other libraries will load the data from common image formats (like .png), then you pass that data to say Direct3D and tell it to create a texture using that image data, then you tell Direct3D to draw that texture onto the screen.

If you're finding this frustrating I really think it would be a bad idea to proceed with DirectX. Have a search for NeHe's OpenGL tutorials, they're what I used to get started with OpenGL programming and they're a great starting point for your own programs (e.g. the texture mapping tutorial loads an image from a .bmp file by hand, then displays that image on a rotating cube.) "Programming" the cube is really simple, so you can start changing it to other shapes to learn how things work.

title: A song I know all too well.
content:
Programming, like any other artform, takes a lot of practise. Putting all your focus on one major project is a recipe for frustration, in my experience. If you really want to understand something, create an experimental side project that does only that. Then make another one that does something interesting. By then it should be a lot simpler to include it into an existing program with a lot of other stuff happening at the same time.

There's a directory on my HDD called Coding Exercises, where I've created programs that helped me understand linked lists, zlib (for importing data from zip files), bitmap fonts, and various other techniques, which did my head in when I tried learning them through larger projects.

My preference at the moment leans toward C (with some slight hybridisation of C++) and Allegro, using Dev-C++/MinGW, so I wouldn't be of much help to your situation. But feel free to pester me on MSN and I'll offer you whatever help I can, assuming I'm not too busy at the time.

I expect pure C++ would require a lot more practise, and DirectX definitely much more so since, when compiled on Windows, Allegro basically acts as a simplified wrapper for DX.

Good luck.

title: Re: A song I know all too well.
content:
I wouldn't bother using assembly at the moment - it's often not worth doing any optimisation until you're sure the code works, so gaining a few FPS here and there during development isn't usually worth the frustration.

I'm not sure what you mean by "programs" to use alpha channels (Paint Shop Pro and GIMP are two programs that let you work with alpha channels) but if you're talking about your own code then I'm sure ImageMagick can provide you with an image's alphamap in a useful format.

You will also probably need code to load sounds and music into memory, and in the case of DirectX that's not enough, because DirectX will only play sounds loaded into DX "buffers" (which can then be hardware accelerated in the case of the SBLive range) so you'll need to load sounds into memory, then put the ones you're using at the time into buffers (and unload the ones you're not using as there are limited buffers available) and then tell DirectX when to play which buffer, etc, etc. Did I mention DirectX was hard??? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

And of course with music, you'll probably need to write a music player as well, because aside from the custom DirectMusic format DirectX only plays sounds, so you'll need to synthesise the music yourself and hand it over to DX as a single continuous sound permanently occupying one of those buffers.

I guess now you can see why so many fangames are created in point-and-click game creation programs, and why many game companies buy other companies' game engines to save developing their own [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: A song I know all too well.
content:
Well, after mulling over my options, I've finally decided to re-start the program in GameMaker.

GameMaker7 has fixed a few of the problems I was having (specifically, it now allows for custumozed alpha channels).

Now, I'm thinking of a way to fix my collision checking problems; I've got a code:

Step function (Each time GM re-draws the screen, it does this[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
[quote]Quote:[hr]
Velocity_Y += Grav //Re-adjusts Velocity for gravitational acceleration

if place_free(x,y+Velocity_Y) //If no object lies in the distance to be covered
{
y = Velocity_Y //Then, go that distance
}

if !place_free(x,y+Velocity_Y) && !(Velocity_Y = 0) //If something does lie between
{
Y_Buffer = Velocity_Y //Create a buffer to test where it is
do
{
Y_Buffer -= 1 //Take one pixel away from the max distance
}
until (!place_free(x,y+Y_Buffer)) //Until that distance triggers this switch
y += Y_Buffer //Add that distance the displacement
Velocity_Y = 0 //Since it is now on the ground, stop speeding
}
[hr][/quote]

However, it creates an infinite loop, and honestly don't know why. So, I'll be looking over this problem for the next few days/weeks (lol). Until next time, kids...~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

If so, I suggest you get some sleep [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] [url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

content:

Well, that might make sense, but its still doing some odd stuff in my GM compiler. Still, it should only repeat this text part every screen draw, not jump back to that loop (And becides, that says "When Velocity_Y does not equal zero").~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

I believe what he's getting at is you're using the single equals sign, setting the value to zero every time, instead of a double for testing equality.

Hmm... but wouldn't that return TRUE, thus resulting in !(TRUE), ie. FALSE, and skip the cycle anyway? Game Maker syntax looks slightly confusing.

title: Re: ==
content:
Yeah, I think I have a sign wrong some where, or else this type of script just doesn't work in GML.

Well, GML is a bit of an odd language, but I think I did that "not equal to" part wrong.

EDIT: Nevermind, I got it workin'. Now, I have no idea if this'll work all the time, but altleast I've got a workable collision system into place, so I can now play around with some physics (Well, I had some physics before, but very limited). =P~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: ==

Well, I'd also like to announce that my game is going to have even more neat features than I announced last time. But, you'll have to wait a while until I get release my demo. *sigh* But I'm counting my chickens before they hatch, so I digress.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

title: grapics library
content:
If you are haveing a hard time using DirectX you can always try SDL ([url=http://www.libsdl.org).]www.libsdl.org).[/url]
It's fairly simple to use, it's portable and quiet powerfull.
I have used it myself for a couple of projects, so if you need any help with it, feel free to ask.

Anyway, good luck with this project!

title: Re: grapics library
content:
Hmm... Well, I suppose an update wouldn't kill. One thing I love about this project is that ideas are never short, so I'm always thinking out one new aspect of the over all engine, or a "wouldn't it be neat if I..." type of things. This is a really cool project.

As for updates:
All right, collision programming has been completed with 100% satisfaction. Dynamics programming is all most all done, but friction is giving me a little trouble. I'm sure I just made a dumb error.

Anyways, next comes incline planes (Which I think I know how to work very easily, I'm hoping this idea will work) and that finishes the physics needed for a quick demo. I've been compiling graphics to get uploaded into my GML file... Then, I do a lot of other engine programming, like AI and the Keen engine (shouldn't be hard to convert current engine). Then I do level design and uploading all my graphics.... Should be interesting.

Also, I have a working Menu level.

I dunno when a demo will come out, but my target date is over the summer. I doubt June, but maybe July (Heh, it'll be a year then since I started this project!).~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Hm..
content:
Well, this project has officially been up for a year.

One would think that I would need to have something finished, wouldn't they, lol?

Well, I do in fact have a tester alpha demo running around; I gave an early one to Levellass and an earlier one to DaVince. The physics engine, as far as it's basic components go, are working great. (As evidenced by the engine itself) So, programming past here shouldn't be too hard, from a physics angle anyways.

The real problem is graphics. I have about 7 re-done tiles that create my "purple plat" (The purple ground found on Vorticon VI), and one Keen image loaded into the game. Which is about what I have done --I have a finished animations of him running left, but not right. I have shells (outlined images meant to show movement, but not textured or shaded) for all of Keen's animations, however; also, I have some of the items done. That's about it.

I've tons of work to do, and really, that little demo is about as far as I'm going to get this summer, I think. I'm sorry to those who want to see what this game can be, but I jsut don't feel like throwing everything I've got at this game. I've got the ideas, and now the ability, but I need time. Not just schedule time, but a lot of time (like months) to re-do the basic animations and tiles. Once that happens, I'll start on level design (Actually, it's pretty fun for the basic play-testing level I designed for de-bugging).


So, happy first b-day, CKTA.

Keep it up!  This looks to me like it has a lot of potential, and we don't like it when fangames with potential go unfinished. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] [img]http://i91.photobucket.com/albums/k284/KeegTech/WarholDopefishPNG2.png[/img]

title: Re: :)
content:
UPDATE:


Yeah, not good. I did a LOT of work prior to leaving off to Florida in early August. However, I'm still behind, and now:

Well, I'm finally in college. I just simply do not have a lot of time... However, in my calculus III class we're doing advanced discussion of vectors, and it's giving me a lot of ideas for how I could much more effectively describe my engine. I have started the basic mathematical premises of the idea, and probably will continue using it (Coolest part is that it can be converted easily to 3-space, but just bi-metric 2-space)

Work has not been done on this game in just under 2 months, so while this still is not on ice, it's not exactly the number one thing on my plate. I did expressly take me 200 MB+ video game project file and put it on my new laptop, but yeah... I'm really, really busy.


So, this weekend I hope I'll be able to get my hands on a mouse for my laptop ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: :)
content:
Well, a little less than a month later and the project is back up. Finally got the hardware (mouse and USB drive) to start working on the animation of this game again.

Graphics will, as ever, take forever. I don't expect it to be too soon before my graphics are completely up and running for a basic demo.

The engine I'm leaving alone for the moment, though I know that I'll be developing a fluid mechanics engine soon enough. (I'm learning the basics of hydrodynamics right now; it's not too bad, but there are still a few things, like matrices, that I am not too familiar with)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...
